page.title: 12Ecology Shenley & Whaddon
page.content: There are 3 main areas of woodland: Oakhill Wood, Shenley Wood and Howe Park. Smaller areas near Whaddon are all that remains of an ancient forest where some oak trees are 1000 years old. The Forestry Commission owns Oakhill Wood and woodlands around Whaddon where they have planted conifers in amongst the indigenous stock. Oakhill Wood is divided up in a grid of bridleways and firebreaks. There are a number of footpaths and bridleways including a section of the North Buckinghamshire Way, often muddy in winter, and some though marked on the map have since disappeared. You may see animals such as deer foxes and badgers in the woods. The land is slightly undulatind and is interspersed with many brooks and small ponds, some the remains of ancient moats and medieval fishponds.
